8. Investment Program Summary
The investment project will finance improvement of the Dhaka-Sylhet section of National Highway No. 2, with design features to
address the needs of the elderly, women, children, and the differently abled, and disaster and climate risks. The project road
connects to the border with India via the Sylhet-Tamabil section, and will improve the efficiency, connectivity, and safety of the
Dhaka-Sylhet trade corridor. The investment project will also assist the Roads and Highways Department (RHD) in
strengthening its capacity for road safety and asset maintenance, in part through the attached transaction technical assistance.
Impact: An efficient, sustainable, safe and regionally balanced transport system developed.
Outcome: Mobility, safety, and regional trade along the Dhaka-Sylhet corridor road improved.
Outputs: (i) The Dhaka-Sylhet corridor road upgraded with enhanced road safety, elderly, women, children, and differently
abled- responsive, and climate- and disaster-resilient features,  and (ii) Institutional capacity of the Roads and Highways
Department enhanced
Implementation Arrangements: Ministry of Road Transport and Bridges will be the executing agency.
Project Readiness: The project readiness is high; the complete scope to be financed by the multitranche financing facility has 
been appraised by ADB, and the impact of the prevailing pandemic on project preparation is insubstantial. The RHD completed 
the detailed design in December 2020. The development project proposal was approved by the government in February 2021. 
Environmental and social due diligence have been completed for the entire alignment. To minimize start-up delays, the RHD 
has been implementing preparatory activities for land acquisition since September 2019. Utility shifting is also underway with the
budget approved by the Ministry of Road Transport and Bridges, and advance funds transfers to utility corporations are 
anticipated to begin by September. Advance contracting is underway too and the RHD is targeting the award of the first 
ADB-financed contract in December 2021.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the South Asia 
Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) Dhaka–Sylhet Corridor Road Investment Project.1 
The report also describes the proposed technical assistance (TA) for Institutional Strengthening 
of the Roads and Highways Department (RHD) on Road Safety and Maintenance, and if the 
Board approves the proposed MFF, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, 
approve the TA and administration of the TA, as applicable.2 
 
2.  The investment project will finance improvement of the Dhaka–Sylhet section of National 
Highway No. 2 (N2), with design features to address the needs of the elderly, women, children, 
and the differently abled, and disaster and climate risks.3 The project road connects to the border 
with India via the Sylhet–Tamabil section, and will improve the efficiency, connectivity, and safety 
of  the  Dhaka–Sylhet  trade  corridor.  The  investment  project  will  also  assist  the  RHD  in 
strengthening its capacity for road safety and asset maintenance, in part through the attached 
transaction  TA.  The  investment  project  and  the  transaction  TA  are  included  in  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) country operations business plan for Bangladesh, 2021–2023.4 
 
II.  RATIONALE 
 
3.  Development context. Growth and development in Bangladesh between 2000 and 2019 
have been significant. Annual economic growth has averaged 6.3%, poverty has been halved, 
and the country has become a key player in the global value chain for ready-made garments.5 
Bangladesh has a young, growing population, and given its location between South Asia and 
Southeast Asia, it can develop into an economic powerhouse by expanding exports of labor-
intensive goods. However, infrastructure deficiencies remain a key challenge to achieving this 
goal. Poor transport infrastructure in particular raises costs, reduces competitiveness, and is a 
major barrier to expanding intraregional trade. 
 
4.  Road transport in Bangladesh. Road transport is Bangladesh’s dominant mode, with a 
modal share of over 70% of passenger traffic and 60% of freight traffic.6 Road traffic has grown 
at an average rate of over 6.6% per year between 2016 and 2020.7 The number of vehicles has 
increased by 15% annually since 2015, reaching 4.4 million in 2020.8 The key challenges for 
Bangladesh’s  roads  are  limited  capacity,  deteriorating  condition,  missing  links  across  the 
country’s many rivers, and a mixture of traffic of differing speeds.9 Globally, Bangladesh ranks 
100th out of 141 countries in terms of quality of its overall transport infrastructure, and 108th in 
the quality of its roads,  lagging behind neighboring countries.10 The suboptimal quality of its road 
network is affecting the country’s logistics performance. Bangladesh ranks 100th out of 160

5.  Road map. To maintain its middle-income country status, Bangladesh needs to continue 
its export-driven economic growth, which in turn demands an efficient, multimodal transport 
system, with roads as the centerpiece. The government aims to upgrade the country’s national 
highways to international standards, especially those forming part of subregional trade corridors 
and connecting major development and industry centers. This will lower logistics costs, increase 
competitiveness, and facilitate expansion of the country’s production base.13 To meet this goal, 
Bangladesh  needs  to  ensure  adequate  funding  and  address  constraints  in  planning, 
implementation, and maintenance capacity. This will also demand holistic planning integrated with 
urban and industry development strategies. Formulation of a long-term strategy for sustainability 
of road assets is another priority. 
 
6.  Dhaka–Sylhet corridor. Upgrading of the Dhaka–Sylhet corridor—which forms the main 
part  of  N2  and  SASEC  Road  Corridor  No.  5—has  been the  government’s top  priority for 
completing the country’s multimodal transport system.14 When complete, the corridor will open a 
new trade route that connects the port city of Chattogram via Dhaka and Sylhet to the border with 
India’s northeastern states through the three land ports of Akhaura, Sheola, and Tamabil, and 
thereby to Bhutan and Myanmar. It will also improve the connectivity of SASEC Corridor No. 2 
(passing from Kolkata in India through Benapole) and SASEC Corridor No. 5 (connecting via 
Dhaka to Sylhet). This will reduce congestion on the Dhaka–Chattogram corridor on the National 
Highway No. 1 by allowing more goods, especially raw materials, to be imported via Tamabil and 
transported along the Dhaka–Sylhet corridor. The wider economic impact of such improved 
connectivity is estimated at about $134 million annually upon opening of the upgraded corridor, 
with benefits that reach far beyond the immediate areas along the project road, and include most 
of Bangladesh and a large part of northeast India.15 
 
7.  Economic and multimodal development. The Dhaka–Sylhet corridor is the backbone 
of the planned Northeast Bangladesh Economic Corridor (NEBEC).16 The NEBEC is expected to 
consolidate and promote key industries in northeast Bangladesh, such as energy generation and 
construction materials production, and better integrate these with economic centers elsewhere in 
Bangladesh.17 This will help diversify the country’s industrial base and equitably distribute export-
led growth beyond the Dhaka–Chattogram area. Multimodal transport planning is a key strategy 
for NEBEC development, with the Dhaka–Sylhet road as its spine; it fits well into the rail system, 
especially the Dhaka–Chattogram corridor, Chattogram port, and Matarbari port (which is under 
development).18 In combination with the Northeast Economic Corridor being prepared in India, 
the NEBEC will help form an economic and urban agglomeration in the center of Asia.19

8.  However, the existing Dhaka‒Sylhet road has only two lanes with no provision for slow-
moving and light traffic, leading to capacity constraints and significant safety risks. This has 
prevented the Dhaka–Sylhet corridor from meeting the need for a vital subregional trade corridor, 
or providing inclusive mobility to the poor and vulnerable living along the corridor. The situation is 
further  exacerbated  by  climate  change,  which  increases  flooding  risks,  particularly  in  the 
northeastern wetland districts, where low-lying areas remain submerged for 4–6 months during 
pre-monsoon and monsoon seasons. 
 
 
9.  Policy framework. The government has three main policy documents for the road sector.
The successive five-year plans have set forth the policy framework, strategies, and targets for 
realizing the goal of becoming an upper middle-income country by 2031 and eradicating poverty 
by 2041.20 They recognize the importance of road transport as the core of an efficient multimodal 
transport network to facilitate regional trade and promote industrial growth, and thereby sustain 
the country’s export-led growth. The Eighth Five Year Plan (2020–2025) continues the emphasis 
from  previous  plans  on  transformational  transport  projects  that  improve  mobility,  facilitate 
international trade, and improve implementation capacity of the RHD for timely completion of such 
road projects and public–private partnerships (PPP) to ease funding constraints.21 In terms of 
physical investment, it places greater emphasis on improving heavily trafficked intercity corridors 
by widening these key roads. 
 
10.  The Road Master Plan (2009) serves as the priority 20-year investment program in the 
road sector. 22 It aims to (i) preserve the RHD’s road assets, (ii) develop a strategic and better 
connected RHD road network to promote the country’s economic growth, (iii) improve road safety, 
and (iv) strengthen the RHD’s institutional capacity. The Road Master Plan formulated the Road 
Sector Policy to realize these goals, and recommends (i) integrated planning; (ii) a higher priority 
on road maintenance, including mainstreaming of routine maintenance; and (iii) better target-
setting for road conditions, controlling overloading, and improving road safety. The policy was 
accompanied by a list of proposed interventions, which were integrated into the successive 5-
year plans. 
 
11.  The National Integrated Multimodal Transport Policy (2013) aims to improve the efficiency 
and  sustainability  of  transport  services  through  integrated  planning  to  contribute  to  the 
government’s goals of sustained economic growth and better integration with other priorities (e.g., 
the environment, land use planning, and social services).23 The key implication for the road sector 
is a shift from continued investment in construction of many new roads to maintaining and using 
assets  effectively.  Specific  strategies to  achieve  this  include  prioritizing  road maintenance, 
collecting user charges on select roads, and completing strategic capacity improvement works on 
major congestion points on the RHD network. 
 
12.  The RHD has improved the key national highways to enhance connectivity between 
Dhaka and major economic centers such as Chattogram and the Padma Multipurpose Bridge. On 
the SASEC Corridor No. 5, the government is upgrading (i) the Sylhet–Tamabil section with 
assistance from the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, and (ii) the Ashuganj–Sarail section 
with assistance from the Exim Bank of India. This will connect to the Shillong–Dawki section 
across the Indian  border,  which  is  being  improved  with  help  from  the  Japan  International

13.  Strategic  context.  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  Bangladesh,  2016‒2020 
emphasizes the following priority areas of investment: (i) easing infrastructure constraints by 
undertaking transformational investments in key sectors including transport; and (ii) promoting 
economic  corridor  development  by  connecting  urban  growth  centers;  fostering  diversified 
industrialization; and linking to national, regional, and global markets and supply chains.27 It also 
prioritizes deepening regional cooperation and integration to create new economic opportunities. 
The MFF aligns well with these strategies by continuing ADB’s engagement in the development 
of the key SASEC corridors and supporting the key transport infrastructure in the NEBEC. 
 
14.  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic  Cooperation.  The  ADB-supported  SASEC 
framework highlights transport and trade facilitation among its operational priorities. Since 2001, 
SASEC member countries have implemented 66 projects costing about $14.3 billion, including 43 
transport projects worth $11.4 billion. Its latest operational plan supports the government’s vision 
for increased trade and economic development by including the widening of the Dhaka‒Sylhet 
section of the N2 in its priority transport projects (footnote 14). Under the SASEC program, ADB 
is also supporting the government’s customs policy reform and trade and transport infrastructure 
development, including expanding the capacity of key land ports (e.g., Akhaura and Tamabil).28 
This  assistance  will  contribute  to  holistic  development  that  centers  on  strategic  trade  and 
economic corridors. 
 
15.  Lessons. ADB has provided ongoing support to develop and upgrade Bangladesh’s 
national highway systems, including the key SASEC corridors. In 2012, ADB approved a $198 
million loan for the SASEC Road Connectivity Project to improve the connectivity of the SASEC 
Corridor No. 2 by upgrading the two-lane road to a four-lane road with slow-moving vehicular 
traffic (SMVT) service lanes on both sides (footnote 24). The SASEC Dhaka–Northwest Corridor 
Road Project, Phase 2, approved in 2017, is a multitranche financing facility in the amount of up 
to $1,200.0 million and will upgrade the remaining section of the corridor.29 Based on the 
implementation of these projects, the following lessons have been incorporated in the design of 
the MFF: (i) quality assurance of detailed designs including cost estimates; (ii) utilization of 
advance  contracting  and  safeguard  actions  to  minimize  start-up  delays;  (iii)  long-term 
engagement for institutional reforms; and (iv) support for safeguards actions.

V.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
32.  The engineering designs are being optimized for economy, construction efficiency, road 
safety, and social inclusiveness following applicable international and national design standards. 
To increase resilience against overloading and extreme weather conditions such as severe heat 
and high precipitation, polymer modified bitumen will be used as the pavement material.45 A 
climate risk and vulnerability assessment was prepared for the investment project. Climate 
change risks have been addressed in the project design by (i) increased embankment height in 
critical portions, (ii) improved bridge designs, (iii) increased linear and cross drainage capacities, 
and (iv) the use of PMB for increasing resilience to temperature extremes (para. 28). The 
contracts will incorporate performance-based maintenance for 6 years as part of PPP initiatives.46 
The  project  implementation  consultant  will  conduct  road  safety  audits  during  the  design, 
construction, and maintenance stages. The construction cost estimates were reviewed in detail, 
and confirmed as responsive to the design necessitated by the project-specific requirements.47 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
33.  Economic analysis. The economic analysis was carried out by comparing the societal 
cost of transportation with and without the project, taking into consideration the benefits of 
improved levels of service on the project road sections. The project benefits will include reduced 
vehicle operating costs, travel time, and road accidents; and increased trade and other economic 
activities. The economic internal rate of return, taking into consideration vehicle operating cost 
and travel time savings, is estimated at 14.2%, indicating that the investment is economically 
viable. A sensitivity analysis testing the effects of possible unfavorable scenarios resulting from 
changes in the key parameters that determine the project costs and benefits indicated that the 
level of economic viability remained satisfactory. Furthermore, the investment project is expected 
to generate wider economic benefits in many other districts of Bangladesh beyond Dhaka or 
Sylhet  as  well  as  in  the  northeast  region  in  India,  demonstrating  its  potential  as  a  major 
subregional route, offering alternatives to the existing trade routes via Southwest Bangladesh and 
Chattogram (footnote 15). 
 
34.  Financial sustainability. The investment project will be implemented with performance-
based maintenance included in the contract for an extended period of 6 years after construction. 
The government has substantially increased the allocation for maintenance from $88 million in 
fiscal year (FY) 2016 to $125 million in FY2020 for national highways. As a result, the proportion 
of roads in good to fair condition increased from 40% to 63% in that period. The average per km 
actual expenditure for national highways under RHD maintenance budget amounted to $27,957 
during FY2016–FY2020. Upon completion of performance-based maintenance under the project, 
recurrent costs associated with the project road sections are estimated to be $12,482 per km 
annually. The performance-based maintenance included in the construction contracts will support 
increased efficiency in routine maintenance through the engagement of the private sector in the 
initial  years  upon  construction.  Furthermore,  the  use  of  PMB  for  pavements  will  increase 
resilience of the project road to heavier traffic, overloading, and extreme temperature, and result 
in longer intervals between periodic maintenance. The annual maintenance budget requirement

international trade with neighboring countries; enhance transport facilities between Dhaka and 
Sylhet and adjacent areas; and provide easier access to larger markets and social services and/or 
facilities such as markets, health facilities, schools, and workplaces. Jobs generated during the 
construction and maintenance stages could help increase household incomes, and contribute to 
poverty reduction. 
 
38.  Social.  Road  safety  remains  a  major  challenge,  with  pedestrians,  bicyclists,  and 
motorcyclists accounting for 80% of fatalities. The investment project is expected to reduce road 
accidents and fatalities through the inclusion of key safety design features, notably SMVT lanes
